intro: Mentha terebinthinacea, commonly known as the Turkish mint, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that have a distinctive menthol scent. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pale blue to violet, and it blooms from late spring to early summer. Mentha terebinthinacea is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb due to its refreshing aroma and potential health benefits.
